questions.question: The endocrine glands lack:
questions.explanation: Endocrine glands lack ducts and are hence called ductless glands. Their secretions are called hormones. (NCERT Page 248)

questions.question: Hormones are secreted by:
questions.explanation: Hormones are non-nutrient chemicals which act as intercellular messengers and are produced in trace amounts by endocrine glands. (NCERT Page 248)

questions.question: The study of endocrine glands and hormones is called:
questions.explanation: The study of endocrine glands and hormones is called endocrinology. (NCERT Page 248)

questions.question: The hypothalamus contains groups of neurosecretory cells called:
questions.explanation: The hypothalamus contains several groups of neurosecretory cells called nuclei which produce hormones. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: The hypothalamus produces two types of hormones:
questions.explanation: These hormones regulate the synthesis and secretion of pituitary hormones. The hypothalamus produces releasing hormones (which stimulate secretion of pituitary hormones) and inhibiting hormones (which inhibit secretions of pituitary hormones). (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: GnRH (Gonadotrophin releasing hormone) stimulates the secretion of:
questions.explanation: GnRH (gonadotrophin releasing hormone) stimulates the pituitary synthesis and release of gonadotrophins. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: Somatostatin from hypothalamus inhibits the secretion of:
questions.explanation: Somatostatin from the hypothalamus inhibits the secretion of growth hormone from the pituitary. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: The hormones produced by hypothalamus reach the pituitary gland through:
questions.explanation: The hormones produced by hypothalamus reach the pituitary gland through a portal circulatory system and regulate the functions of the anterior pituitary. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: The pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain in a bony cavity called:
questions.explanation: The pituitary gland is located in a bony cavity called sella turcica and is attached to the hypothalamus by a stalk. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: The pituitary gland is divided into:
questions.explanation: The pituitary gland is divided anatomically into an adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary) and a neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary). The adenohypophysis consists of pars distalis (anterior lobe) and pars intermedia (intermediate lobe). (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: The pars distalis (anterior lobe of pituitary) secretes:
options: Six hormones (GH, PRL, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH)
questions.explanation: Pars distalis produces growth hormone (GH), prolactin (PRL), thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: Growth hormone (GH) stimulates:
questions.explanation: Growth hormone stimulates growth and development of the body. Oversecretion of GH stimulates abnormal growth of the body leading to gigantism. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: Gigantism is caused by:
questions.explanation: Oversecretion of GH stimulates abnormal growth of the body leading to gigantism. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: Dwarfism is caused by:
questions.explanation: Undersecretion of GH in childhood leads to stunted growth resulting in pituitary dwarfism. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: Acromegaly is caused by:
questions.explanation: Excess secretion of growth hormone in adults especially in middle age can result in severe disfigurement called acromegaly (enlargement of hands, feet, and jaw bones). (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: Prolactin (PRL) regulates:
options: Growth of mammary glands and milk production
questions.explanation: Prolactin regulates the growth of the mammary glands and formation of milk in them. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone) stimulates:
options: Thyroid gland to synthesise and secrete thyroid hormones
questions.explanation: TSH stimulates the synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones from the thyroid gland. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: ACTH (Adrenocorticotrophic Hormone) stimulates:
options: Adrenal cortex to synthesise and secrete glucocorticoids
questions.explanation: ACTH stimulates the synthesis and secretion of steroid hormones called glucocorticoids from adrenal cortex. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: LH and FSH are together called:
questions.explanation: LH and FSH stimulate gonadal activity and hence are called gonadotrophins. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: In males, LH stimulates:
options: Synthesis and secretion of androgens by Leydig cells
questions.explanation: In males, LH stimulates the synthesis and secretion of hormones called androgens from testis (Leydig cells or interstitial cells). (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: In males, FSH stimulates:
questions.explanation: In males, FSH and androgens regulate spermatogenesis. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: In females, LH induces:
options: Ovulation of fully mature Graafian follicle and maintains corpus luteum
questions.explanation: In females, LH induces ovulation of fully mature follicles (graafian follicles) and maintains the corpus luteum. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: In females, FSH stimulates:
options: Growth and development of ovarian follicles
questions.explanation: In females, FSH stimulates growth and development of the ovarian follicles. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: The pars intermedia secretes only one hormone called:
questions.explanation: Pars intermedia secretes only one hormone called melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH). However, in humans, the pars intermedia is almost merged with pars distalis. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: MSH acts on:
options: Melanocytes (pigment cells) and regulates skin pigmentation
questions.explanation: MSH acts on melanocytes (pigment containing cells) and regulates pigmentation of the skin. (NCERT Page 249)

questions.question: The posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) stores and releases:
questions.explanation: Neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary) stores and releases two hormones called oxytocin and vasopressin, which are actually synthesised by the hypothalamus and transported axonally to neurohypophysis. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Oxytocin and vasopressin are synthesised by the:
questions.explanation: Oxytocin and vasopressin are actually synthesised by the hypothalamus and transported axonally to neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary) for storage and release. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Oxytocin acts on:
options: Smooth muscles of uterus (during parturition) and mammary glands (milk ejection)
questions.explanation: Oxytocin acts on the smooth muscles of our body and stimulates their contraction. In females, it stimulates a vigorous contraction of uterus at the time of child birth, and milk ejection from the mammary gland. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Vasopressin is also called:
questions.explanation: Vasopressin acts mainly at the kidney and stimulates resorption of water and electrolytes by the distal tubules and thereby reduces loss of water through urine (diuresis). Hence, it is also called anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: ADH deficiency causes:
questions.explanation: An under secretion of ADH results in the production of large quantities of dilute urine, a disease known as diabetes insipidus. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: The pineal gland is located on:
questions.explanation: The pineal gland is located on the dorsal side of forebrain. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: The pineal gland secretes:
questions.explanation: Pineal secretes a hormone called melatonin. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Melatonin is involved in:
options: Regulation of 24-hour (diurnal) rhythm of our body
questions.explanation: Melatonin plays a very important role in the regulation of a 24-hour (diurnal) rhythm of our body, e.g., maintaining sleep-wake cycle, body temperature, etc. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Melatonin also influences:
options: Metabolism, pigmentation, menstrual cycle, and defence capability
questions.explanation: Melatonin also influences metabolism, pigmentation, the menstrual cycle as well as our defence capability. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: The thyroid gland is located on either side of:
questions.explanation: The thyroid gland is situated on either side of the trachea (windpipe). (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: The two lobes of the thyroid gland are connected by:
questions.explanation: The thyroid gland is composed of two lobes which are interconnected with a thin flap of connective tissue called isthmus. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: The structural and functional unit of the thyroid gland is:
questions.explanation: The thyroid gland is composed of follicles and stromal tissue. Each thyroid follicle is composed of follicular cells, enclosing a cavity filled with colloid. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: The hormones secreted by thyroid follicular cells are:
questions.explanation: Follicular cells synthesise two hormones, tetraiodothyronine or thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Iodine is essential for:
questions.explanation: Iodine is essential for the normal rate of hormone synthesis in the thyroid. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Thyroid hormones regulate:
questions.explanation: Thyroid hormones play an important role in the regulation of the basal metabolic rate. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Thyroid hormones also support:
options: Process of RBC formation, metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins and fats
questions.explanation: Thyroid hormones also support the process of red blood cell formation. Thyroid hormones control the metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins and fats. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Maintenance of water and electrolyte balance is also influenced by:
questions.explanation: Thyroid hormones are also required for maintenance of water and electrolyte balance. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Goitre is caused by:
questions.explanation: Deficiency of iodine in our diet results in hypothyroidism and enlargement of the thyroid gland, commonly called goitre. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Hypothyroidism during pregnancy causes:
options: Cretinism (stunted growth and mental retardation in baby)
questions.explanation: Hypothyroidism during pregnancy causes defective development and maturation of the growing baby leading to stunted growth (cretinism), mental retardation, low intelligence quotient, abnormal skin, deaf-mutism, etc. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Myxoedema is characterised by:
options: Low BMR, puffiness of face and hands in adults
questions.explanation: In adults, hypothyroidism may lead to a condition called myxoedema, which is characterised by a low metabolic rate, increase in body weight, tendency to retain water in tissues, and puffiness of face and hands. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Exophthalmic goitre (Graves' disease) is caused by:
questions.explanation: Hyperthyroidism adversely affects the body physiology. A condition called Graves' disease or exophthalmic goitre is caused due to hypersecretion of thyroid hormones. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Calcitonin is secreted by:
questions.explanation: The thyroid gland also secretes a protein hormone called thyrocalcitonin (TCT) which regulates the blood calcium levels. TCT is secreted by the parafollicular cells (C cells). (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: Thyrocalcitonin (calcitonin) regulates:
questions.explanation: Thyrocalcitonin (TCT) regulates the blood calcium levels. It lowers calcium levels in the blood. (NCERT Page 250)

questions.question: In humans, there are how many parathyroid glands?
questions.explanation: In humans, four parathyroid glands are present on the back side of the thyroid gland, one pair each in the two lobes of the thyroid gland. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The parathyroid glands are located on the:
questions.explanation: In humans, four parathyroid glands are present on the back side of the thyroid gland. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is also called:
questions.explanation: The parathyroid glands secrete a peptide hormone called parathyroid hormone (PTH), also called as Collip's hormone. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: PTH increases:
questions.explanation: PTH increases the Ca2+ levels in the blood. It acts on bones and stimulates the process of bone resorption (calcium release from bones). (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: PTH and TCT (calcitonin) are:
options: Antagonistic to each other in calcium regulation
questions.explanation: PTH increases blood calcium while TCT (calcitonin) decreases blood calcium. They are antagonistic to each other in the regulation of calcium levels in blood. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The thymus gland is located:
options: Behind sternum on the ventral side of aorta
questions.explanation: The thymus gland is a lobular structure located on the dorsal side of the heart and the aorta (behind sternum, ventral side of aorta). (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The thymus secretes:
questions.explanation: The thymus gland secretes the peptide hormones called thymosins. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Thymosins play a role in:
questions.explanation: Thymosins play a major role in the differentiation of T-lymphocytes, which provide cell-mediated immunity. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The thymus is degenerated in:
questions.explanation: The thymus is quite large at the time of birth but keeps reducing in size with age and by the time puberty is attained it reduces to a very small size. It is degenerated in old individuals. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The adrenal glands are located:
options: At the anterior part of each kidney
questions.explanation: Our body has one pair of adrenal glands, one at the anterior part of each kidney. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The adrenal gland has two components:
questions.explanation: The gland is composed of two types of tissues. The centrally located tissue is called the adrenal medulla, and outside this lies the adrenal cortex. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The adrenal cortex is divided into three layers called:
options: Zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis
questions.explanation: The adrenal cortex can be divided into three layers, called zona glomerulosa (outer layer), zona fasciculata (middle layer) and zona reticularis (inner layer). (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The hormones of adrenal cortex are commonly called:
questions.explanation: The adrenal cortex secretes many hormones, commonly called as corticoids. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Mineralocorticoids like aldosterone are secreted by:
questions.explanation: The adrenal cortex secretes corticoids, which are of three types: mineralocorticoids (mainly aldosterone) secreted by zona glomerulosa. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Aldosterone acts on:
options: Renal tubules and stimulates reabsorption of Na+ and excretion of K+
questions.explanation: Aldosterone acts mainly at the renal tubules and stimulates the reabsorption of Na+ and water and excretion of K+ and phosphate ions. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Glucocorticoids like cortisol are secreted by:
questions.explanation: Glucocorticoids (mainly cortisol) are secreted by zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Cortisol stimulates:
questions.explanation: Cortisol is involved in carbohydrate metabolism. It stimulates gluconeogenesis (formation of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources), lipolysis (breakdown of fats), and proteolysis (breakdown of proteins). (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Glucocorticoids also have:
questions.explanation: Glucocorticoids suppress the immune response and produce anti-inflammatory reactions. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: Sex corticoids (androgens) are secreted by:
questions.explanation: Sexcorticoids (mainly androgens) are secreted by zona reticularis. (NCERT Page 251)

questions.question: The adrenal medulla secretes:
questions.explanation: Adrenal medulla secretes two hormones called adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine). These are commonly called catecholamines. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Adrenaline is also called:
questions.explanation: Adrenaline is commonly called the 'hormone of fight or flight' as it is rapidly secreted in response to stress of any kind and during emergency situations. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Catecholamines increase:
options: Heart rate, strength of heart contraction, and blood pressure
questions.explanation: Catecholamines increase alertness, pupillary dilation, piloerection (raising of hairs), sweating, etc. Both adrenaline and noradrenaline increase the heart rate, the strength of heart contraction and the rate of respiration. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Catecholamines also stimulate:
options: Breakdown of glycogen (glycogenolysis) resulting in increased blood glucose
questions.explanation: Catecholamines stimulate the breakdown of glycogen resulting in an increased concentration of glucose in blood. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Addison's disease is caused by:
questions.explanation: Addison's disease is caused by hyposecretion of adrenal cortex hormones. It is characterized by weight loss, muscle weakness, fatigue, low blood pressure, and darkening of the skin. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: The pancreas is a:
questions.explanation: Pancreas is a composite gland which acts as both exocrine and endocrine gland. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: The endocrine part of pancreas is called:
questions.explanation: The endocrine pancreas consists of Islets of Langerhans. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: The islets of Langerhans contain two main types of cells:
questions.explanation: There are about 1 to 2 million Islets of Langerhans in a normal human pancreas representing only 1 to 2 per cent of the pancreatic tissue. The two main types of cells in the Islet of Langerhans are called α-cells and β-cells. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Glucagon is secreted by:
options: Alpha cells of islets of Langerhans
questions.explanation: The α-cells secrete a hormone called glucagon. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Insulin is secreted by:
options: Beta (β) cells of islets of Langerhans
questions.explanation: The β-cells secrete insulin. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Glucagon acts on:
options: Liver cells and stimulates glycogenolysis (increase blood glucose)
questions.explanation: Glucagon acts mainly on the liver cells (hepatocytes) and stimulates glycogenolysis resulting in an increased blood sugar (hyperglycemia). (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Glucagon also stimulates:
questions.explanation: Glucagon also stimulates the process of gluconeogenesis which also contributes to hyperglycemia. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Glucagon is also called:
questions.explanation: Glucagon is a hyperglycemic hormone as it increases blood glucose levels. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Insulin acts on:
options: Hepatocytes and adipocytes and enhances cellular glucose uptake
questions.explanation: Insulin acts mainly on hepatocytes and adipocytes and enhances cellular glucose uptake and utilisation. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Insulin is called:
questions.explanation: Insulin reduces blood glucose level and is therefore called hypoglycemic hormone. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Insulin and glucagon are:
questions.explanation: Insulin is hypoglycemic and glucagon is hyperglycemic. They are antagonistic to each other in regulating blood glucose levels. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Diabetes mellitus is caused by:
options: Deficiency of insulin leading to hyperglycemia and glucosuria
questions.explanation: Prolonged hyperglycemia leads to a complex disorder called diabetes mellitus which is associated with loss of glucose through urine and formation of harmful compounds known as ketone bodies. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: The testis produces:
questions.explanation: A pair of testis is present in the scrotal sac of males. Testis performs dual functions as a primary sex organ as well as an endocrine gland. Testis secretes several male sex hormones called androgens, mainly testosterone. (NCERT Page 252)

questions.question: Androgens regulate:
options: Development, maturation, and functions of male accessory sex organs
questions.explanation: Androgens regulate the development, maturation and functions of the male accessory sex organs like epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles, prostate gland, urethra, etc. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Male secondary sexual characters like facial hair, low voice, etc., are stimulated by:
questions.explanation: Androgens stimulate muscular growth, growth of facial and axillary hair, aggressiveness, low pitch of voice, etc. These are known as male secondary sexual characters. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: The ovary produces:
questions.explanation: Females have a pair of ovaries located in the abdomen. Ovary produces two groups of steroid hormones called estrogen and progesterone. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Oestrogen is produced by:
questions.explanation: Ovary produces estrogen and progesterone. Estrogen is mainly produced by the growing ovarian follicles. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Oestrogen stimulates:
options: Growth and activities of female secondary sex organs and development of female secondary sexual characters
questions.explanation: Estrogen stimulates growth and activities of female secondary sex organs, appearance of female secondary sexual characters (e.g., high pitch of voice, breast enlargement, etc.). (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Progesterone is mainly produced by:
questions.explanation: Progesterone is mainly produced by the corpus luteum after ovulation. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Progesterone supports:
options: Pregnancy (maintenance of endometrium) and acts on mammary glands
questions.explanation: Progesterone supports pregnancy. It also acts on the mammary glands and stimulates the formation of alveoli (small sacs) in the mammary glands. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: The atrial wall of the heart secretes:
questions.explanation: The atrial wall of our heart secretes a very important peptide hormone called atrial natriuretic factor (ANF). (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: ANF causes:
options: Dilation of blood vessels and decrease in blood pressure
questions.explanation: ANF can cause dilation of the blood vessels. This decreases the blood pressure. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: The juxtaglomerular cells of kidney produce:
questions.explanation: The juxtaglomerular cells of kidney produce a peptide hormone called erythropoietin which stimulates erythropoiesis (formation of RBC). (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Erythropoietin stimulates:
questions.explanation: Erythropoietin stimulates erythropoiesis (formation of RBC). (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: The gastrointestinal tract secretes hormones like:
questions.explanation: The gastrointestinal tract secretes four major peptide hormones, namely gastrin, secretin, cholecystokinin (CCK), and gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP). (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Gastrin acts on:
options: Gastric glands and stimulates secretion of HCl and pepsinogen
questions.explanation: Gastrin acts on the gastric glands and stimulates the secretion of hydrochloric acid and pepsinogen. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: Secretin acts on:
options: Exocrine pancreas and stimulates secretion of water and bicarbonate ions
questions.explanation: Secretin acts on the exocrine pancreas and stimulates secretion of water and bicarbonate ions. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: CCK (Cholecystokinin) stimulates:
options: Secretion of pancreatic enzymes and bile juice from gallbladder
questions.explanation: CCK acts on both pancreas and gall bladder and stimulates the secretion of pancreatic enzymes and bile juice, respectively. (NCERT Page 253)

questions.question: GIP (Gastric Inhibitory Peptide):
options: Inhibits gastric secretion and stimulates insulin secretion
questions.explanation: GIP inhibits gastric secretion and motility. It also stimulates insulin secretion. (NCERT Page 253)
